tree.original_reasoning:
We are going to chain three programs.

 Program 1:
   Input: First integer N, then a list of N integers.
   Output: An integer (a)

 Program 2:
   Input: The output of Program 1 is passed as a string to Program 2? But note: Program 2 reads a string with input().

   But note: the first program outputs an integer (a) and the second program expects a string.

   How we handle: The entire output of the first program (which is the integer a) is passed as the input string to the second program.

   Example: if the first program outputs 3, then the second program reads "3".

   However, looking at the second program: it processes a string that can contain 'A', 'B', 'C', etc. But we are passing a string of digits.

   The second program's logic:
     It replaces:
        "A" -> "A"
        "BC" (when found as 'B' followed by 'C') -> "D"
        otherwise, any other character (including single 'B' or others) becomes "X"

     Then it counts the number of "D" that are preceded by a sequence of consecutive "A"s, and for each "D", it adds the count of consecutive "A"s immediately before it (and then resets the count of A on encountering an 'X').

   But note: the input to the second program is the string representation of the integer from the first program. So if the first program outputs 3, then the string is "3". 

   How will the second program process "3"?
      i=0: s[0] is '3' -> which is not 'A' and not 'B', so it becomes 'X'. Then the entire string t becomes "X".

      Then in the counting loop:
        for each char in "X":
          if char is 'X': reset numA to 0.
          else ... skip.

        total remains 0.

   So the second program will output 0.

 Program 3:
   Input: The output of Program 2 (an integer, which we will pass as a string? But note: Program 3 does `N = int(input())` and then uses that N in the function.

   How we chain: The output of Program 2 is passed as the input to Program 3.

   But Program 3 reads a single integer N.

   Example: if Program 2 outputs 0, then Program 3 reads the string "0", converts to integer, and then runs.

Not necessarily: the set must be exactly {'7','5','3'}, so the number must have only these digits and must have at least one of each? Actually, no: the set of digits in the number must be exactly that set. But if the number has only two of them, then the set would have two elements and fail. So the number must have all three digits? Actually, no: the set of distinct digits must be exactly the set {'7','5','3'}. So the number must contain 7,5,3 and no other digit. It can have multiple of each, but the distinct digits must be exactly those three.

   However, note that the program starts with '0'. Then it appends one of the digits. So the numbers are generated as strings and then converted to integers (which removes leading zeros). For example, starting at "0", then we go to "07", which becomes 7 -> the set of digits of 7 is {'7'} -> not equal to {'7','5','3'} -> so not counted.

              for (int i = 0; i < N1; i++) {
                  scanf("%d", &arr[i]);
              }

              // Compute a
              int a = 1;
              int pos = 0;
              for (int i = 1; i < N1; i++) {
                  if (arr[pos] > arr[i]) {
                      a++;
                      pos = i;
                  }
              }
              free(arr);

              // Convert a to a string
              char s[12];
              sprintf(s, "%d", a);

              // Build t
              int len = strlen(s);
              char *t = (char*)malloc(len+1); // we will build t, but note: t will be at most len long? and we know every char becomes one char? so same length.
              int j = 0;
              int i = 0;
              while (i < len) {
                  if (s[i]=='A') {
                      t[j++] = 'A';
                      i++;
                  } else if (s[i]=='B') {
                      if (i+1 < len && s[i+1]=='C') {
                          t[j++] = 'D';
                          i += 2;
                      } else {
                          t[j++] = 'X';
                          i++;
                      }
                  } else {
                      t[j++] = 'X';
                      i++;
                  }
              }
              t[j] = '\0';

              // Count total
              int total = 0;
              int numA = 0;
              for (int k = 0; k < j; k++) {
                  if (t[k]=='X') {
                      numA = 0;
                  } else if (t[k]=='A') {
                      numA++;
                  } else if (t[k]=='D') {
                      total += numA;
                  }
              }
              free(t);

              // Now, call aaa for the third program
              long long result = aaa("0", total);
              printf("%lld\n", result);

              return 0;
          }

          long long aaa(const char *num_str, long long N) {
              // Convert the string to a long long
              long long num_val = atoll(num_str);
              if (num_val > N) {
                  return 0;
              }

              // Convert the number to a string without leading zeros
              char buf[100];
              sprintf(buf, "%lld", num_val);

              // Check the set of digits
              int seen[10] = {0};
              int valid = 1;
              for (int i = 0; buf[i]; i++) {
                  char c = buf[i];
                  if (c < '0' || c > '9') {
                      valid = 0;
                      break;
                  }
                  seen[c-'0'] = 1;
              }

              long long ans = 0;
              if (valid) {
                  // Check if the digits are exactly 3,5,7 and no others
                  if (seen[3] && seen[5] && seen[7]) {
                      // Check for any other digit
                      for (int d = 0; d < 10; d++) {
                          if (d != 3 && d != 5 && d != 7 && seen[d]) {
                              valid = 0;
                              break;
                          }
                      }
                      if (valid) {
                          ans = 1;
                      }
                  }
              }

              // Recurse for each digit in "753"
              const char *digits = "753";
              for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
                  char next_str[100]; // fixed buffer, but the string might be too long? 
                  // We know that the current string length is at most 99 - 1? 
                  int len = strlen(num_str);
                  if (len + 1 < 100) {
                      sprintf(next_str, "%s%c", num_str, digits[i]);
                      ans += aaa(next_str, N);
                  } else {
                      // Skip because the number would be too long? and the value would be huge? 
                      // But note: we break in the next call because the value would be greater than N? 
                      // We can also break? 
                      // Since we are only called with N=0, we break.
                  }
              }

              return ans;
          }
